title: Merkel calls for MORE EU integration to take on Donald Trump as strong Europe
text:
GETTY Theresa May and Angela Merkel are in Malta today for talks I believe the stronger we define our role in the world the better we can manage our transatlantic relationships Angela Merkel 
"I believe the stronger we define our role in the world the better we can manage our transatlantic relationships that’s why for me its is more important to discuss Europe today and not other parts of the world." 
EU leaders are discussing a number of issues today including the EU Army's deployment. 
Mr Trump said last month he would only continue supporting Nato if Brussels dropped its plans for an EU army. GETTY Mrs Merkel and Mrs May visited St John's Cathedral today ahead of talks 
And Mrs Merkel was snubbed for a meeting with Mr Trump, having only spoken to the US president by phone. 
The under-fire chancellor is facing an uphill struggle in her hopes for cohesion among her colleagues in the EU however. 
She is facing mounting pressure from countries struggling to cope with her open door migrant policy. 
Mrs Merkel has been forced to u-turn on her "no limit" refugee policy after revealing this week she is to spend £37bn in taxpayer's money on the crisis in Germany alone this year. 
Illegal trafficking has become rife since Mrs Merkel announced that she would ensure every asylum seeker coming to Germany would get a fair hearing in September 2015. 
But as countries like Italy, Greece, Sweden, France, Malta and others struggle to cope with the crippling demands of people trying to get to Europe she has been forced to u-turn. 
Germany recently passed laws which will limit the number of people, including refugees, who will be able to travel to the country. 
It comes as Mrs Merkel is also facing a backlash from the public reeling from a string of terror attacks including the Christmas market attack in Berlin attacks that killed 12 just weeks ago. 
Speaking to media ahead of the conference she said she intended to update on a new "European asylum system" designed to expedite the removal of criminals. 
Mrs Merkel is reiterating the EU's continued commitment to trying to tackle the problem as it attempts to close off its borders albeit without the same reaction that was sparked when Donald Trump made an executive order to limit migration from seven countries to the United States last week. 
She said: "This is a special summit that will look at the questions of migration, especially with the central Mediterranean and therefore also with Libya. 
"We need a political solution for a stable Libya, we have a lot of work to do that is so far not the case. 
"We are supporting the government of Mr Sarraj but we need a political solution. 
"And we will also try to improve the situation for the refugees in Libya. GETTY Alexis Tsipras, Charles Michel, Francois Hollande, Angela Merkel, Paolo Gentiloni, Andrej Plenkovic 
"We will discuss the new European asylum system, I believe that all in all we are very well prepared to make the next steps. 
"The second step in the council of the 27 we will talk about the preparations for the [Treaty of] Rome. 
The Chancellor’s struggling administration has unveiled a raft of new laws in parliament to help cope with the escalating European migrant crisis. Europe in Crisis
